summary: This is an email forwarding a news article about Alexander Acosta's role in the Jeffrey Epstein non-prosecution plea deal in 2007. The email includes a key quote where Acosta claims he was told to back off the Epstein case because Epstein 'belonged to intelligence'.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney in Miami, later U.S. Secretary of Labor
persons.context: He is the subject of the forwarded article, which details his role in cutting the 2007 non-prosecution plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein and his subsequent explanation that he was told to back off because Epstein 'belonged to intelligence'.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the case. The document references his 2007 non-prosecution plea deal and the claim that he 'belonged to intelligence', which allegedly caused authorities to back off.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: He is listed as a recipient (To:) of this email correspondence.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, cut the 2007 non-prosecution plea deal with one of Epstein's attorneys, effectively ending a federal investigation into Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Plea Deal
events.description: Alexander Acosta, as U.S. Attorney in Miami, cut a non-prosecution plea deal with one of Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys. This deal halted a separate federal investigation into alleged sex crimes with minors and trafficking.

events.title: Email Forwarding Acosta Article
events.description: An email is sent forwarding a Daily Beast article detailing Acosta's comments about the Epstein case during his interview for Labor Secretary.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY (United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: Alexander Acosta claimed he was told Epstein 'belonged to intelligence' and was instructed to leave the case alone.
The 2007 non-prosecution plea deal negotiated by Acosta halted a federal investigation into Epstein's alleged sex crimes with minors and trafficking.
Acosta's handling of the Epstein case was raised during his interview for the position of U.S. Labor Secretary under the Trump administration.
The document is an internal email forwarding a news article, suggesting the topic was under discussion within the U.S. Attorney's Office.
